action.name: Identify Alchemy
action.requirements: You have a {@item alchemist's tools|CRB} (page 287).
entries: You can identify the nature of an alchemical item with 10 minutes of testing using {@item alchemist's tools|CRB}. If your attempt is interrupted in any way, you must start over.

entries.Success: You identify the item and the means of activating it.
entries.Failure: You fail to identify the item but can try again.
entries.Critical Failure: You misidentify the item as another item of the GM's choice.

action.name: Create a Diversion
entries: With a gesture, a trick, or some distracting words, you can create a diversion that draws creatures' attention elsewhere. If you use a gesture or trick, this action gains the {@trait manipulate} trait. If you use distracting words, it gains the {@trait auditory} and {@trait linguistic} traits.

Attempt a single {@skill Deception} check and compare it to the {@skill Perception} DCs of the creatures whose attention you're trying to divert. Whether or not you succeed, creatures you attempt to divert gain a +4 circumstance bonus to their {@skill Perception} DCs against your attempts to Create a Diversion for 1 minute.

entries.Success: You become hidden to each creature whose {@skill Perception} DC is less than or equal to your result. (The {@condition hidden|CRB} condition allows you to {@action Sneak|CRB} away, as described on page 252.) This lasts until the end of your turn or until you do anything except {@action Step|CRB} or use the {@action Hide|CRB} or the {@action Sneak|CRB} action of the {@skill Stealth} skill (pages 251 and 252). If you {@action Strike|CRB} a creature, the creature remains {@condition flat-footed|CRB} against that attack, and you then become {@condition observed|CRB}. If you do anything else, you become {@condition observed|CRB} just before you act unless the GM determines otherwise.
entries.Failure: You don't divert the attention of any creatures whose {@skill Perception} DC exceeds your result, and those creatures are aware you were trying to trick them.

action.name: Impersonate
entries: You create a disguise to pass yourself off as someone or something you are not. Assembling a convincing disguise takes 10 minutes and requires a {@item disguise kit|CRB}, but a simpler, quicker disguise might do the job if you're not trying to imitate a specific individual, at the GM's discretion.

In most cases, creatures have a chance to detect your deception only if they use the {@action Seek|CRB} action to attempt {@skill Perception} checks against your {@skill Deception} DC. If you attempt to directly interact with someone while disguised, the GM rolls a secret {@skill Deception} check for you against that creature's {@skill Perception} DC instead. If you're disguised as a specific individual, the GM might give creatures you interact with a circumstance bonus based on how well they know the person you're imitating, or the GM might roll a secret {@skill Deception} check even if you aren't directly interacting with others.

entries.Success: You trick the creature into thinking you're the person you're disguised as. You might have to attempt a new check if your behavior changes.
entries.Failure: The creature can tell you're not who you claim to be.
entries.Critical Failure: The creature can tell you're not who you claim to be, and it recognizes you if it would know you without a disguise.

action.name: Lie
entries: You try to fool someone with an untruth. Doing so takes at least 1 round, or longer if the lie is elaborate. You roll a single {@skill Deception} check and compare it against the {@skill Perception} DC of every creature you are trying to fool. The GM might give them a circumstance bonus based on the situation and the nature of the lie you are trying to tell. Elaborate or highly unbelievable lies are much harder to get a creature to believe than simpler and more believable lies, and some lies are so big that it's impossible to get anyone to believe them.

At the GM's discretion, if a creature initially believes your lie, it might attempt a {@skill Perception} check later to Sense Motive against your Deception DC to realize it's a lie. This usually happens if the creature discovers enough evidence to counter your statements.

entries.Success: The target believes your lie.
entries.Failure: The target doesn't believe your lie and gains a +4 circumstance bonus against your attempts to Lie for the duration of your conversation. The target is also more likely to be suspicious of you in the future.

action.name: Feint
action.requirements: You are within melee reach of the opponent you attempt to Feint.
entries: With a misleading flourish, you leave an opponent unprepared for your real attack. Attempt a {@skill Deception} check against that opponent's {@skill Perception} DC.

entries.Critical Success: You throw your enemy's defenses against you entirely off. The target is {@condition flat-footed|CRB} against melee attacks that you attempt against it until the end of your next turn.
entries.Success: Your foe is fooled, but only momentarily. The target is {@condition flat-footed|CRB} against the next melee attack that you attempt against it before the end of your current turn.
entries.Critical Failure: Your feint backfires. You are {@condition flat-footed|CRB} against melee attacks the target attempts against you until the end of your next turn.

action.name: Gather Information
entries: You canvass local markets, taverns, and gathering places in an attempt to learn about a specific individual or topic. The GM determines the DC of the check and the amount of time it takes (typically 2 hours, but sometimes more), along with any benefit you might be able to gain by spending coin on bribes, drinks, or gifts.

entries.Success: You collect information about the individual or topic. The GM determines the specifics.
entries.Critical Failure: You collect incorrect information about the individual or topic.

items.name: Legendary
items.entry: information known only to an incredibly select few, or only to extraordinary beings

action.name: Make an Impression
entries: With at least 1 minute of conversation, during which you engage in charismatic overtures, flattery, and other acts of goodwill, you seek to make a good impression on someone to make them temporarily agreeable. At the end of the conversation, attempt a {@skill Diplomacy} check against the Will DC of one target, modified by any circumstances the GM sees fit. Good impressions (or bad impressions, on a critical failure) last for only the current social interaction unless the GM decides otherwise.

entries.Critical Success: The target's attitude toward you improves by two steps.
entries.Success: The target's attitude toward you improves by one step.
entries.Critical Failure: The target's attitude toward you decreases by one step.

info.name: Changing Attitudes
entries: Your influence on NPCs is measured with a set of attitudes that reflect how they view your character. These are only a brief summary of a creature's disposition. The GM will supply additional nuance based on the history and beliefs of the characters you're interacting with, and their attitudes can change in accordance with the story. The attitudes are detailed in the Conditions Appendix and are summarized here.

items: {@b Helpful:} Willing to help you and responds favorably to your requests.
{@b Friendly:} Has a good attitude toward you, but won't necessarily stick their neck out to help you.
{@b Indifferent:} Doesn't care about you either way. (Most NPCs start out indifferent.)
{@b Unfriendly:} Dislikes you and doesn't want to help you.
{@b Hostile:} Actively works against you—and might attack you just because of their dislike.

entries: No one can ever change the attitude of a player character with these skills. You can roleplay interactions with player characters, and even use {@skill Diplomacy} results if the player wants a mechanical sense of how convincing or charming a character is, but players make the ultimate decisions about how their characters respond.

action.name: Request
entries: You can make a request of a creature that's {@condition friendly|CRB} or {@condition helpful|CRB} to you. You must couch the request in terms that the target would accept given their current attitude toward you. The GM sets the DC based on the difficulty of the request. Some requests are unsavory or impossible, and even a helpful NPC would never agree to them.

entries.Critical Success: The target agrees to your request without qualifications.
entries.Success: The target agrees to your request, but they might demand added provisions or alterations to the request.
entries.Failure: The target refuses the request, though they might propose an alternative that is less extreme.
entries.Critical Failure: Not only does the target refuse the request, but their attitude toward you decreases by one step due to the temerity of the request.

action.name: Coerce
entries: With threats either veiled or overt, you attempt to bully a creature into doing what you want. You must spend at least 1 minute of conversation with a creature you can see and that can either see or sense you. At the end of the conversation, attempt an {@skill Intimidation} check against the target's Will DC, modified by any circumstances the GM determines. The attitudes referenced in the effects below are summarized in the Changing Attitudes sidebar on page 246 and described in full in the Conditions Appendix, starting on page 618.

entries.Critical Success: The target gives you the information you seek or agrees to follow your directives so long as they aren't likely to harm the target in any way. The target continues to comply for an amount of time determined by the GM but not exceeding 1 day, at which point the target becomes {@condition unfriendly|CRB} (if they weren't already {@condition unfriendly|CRB} or {@condition hostile|CRB}). However, the target is too scared of you to retaliate—at least in the short term.
entries.Success: As critical success, but once the target becomes {@condition unfriendly|CRB}, they might decide to act against you—for example, by reporting you to the authorities or assisting your enemies.
entries.Failure: The target doesn't do what you say, and if they were not already {@condition unfriendly|CRB} or {@condition hostile|CRB}, they become {@condition unfriendly|CRB}
entries.Critical Failure: The target refuses to comply, becomes {@condition hostile|CRB} if they weren't already, and can't be Coerced by you for at least 1 week.

action.name: Demoralize
entries: With a sudden shout, a well-timed taunt, or a cutting putdown, you can shake an enemy's resolve. Choose a creature within 30 feet of you who you're aware of. Attempt an {@skill Intimidation} check against that target's Will DC. If the target does not understand the language you are speaking, you're not speaking a language, or they can't hear you, you take a –4 circumstance penalty to the check. Regardless of your result, the target is temporarily immune to your attempts to Demoralize it for 10 minutes.

entries.Critical Success: The target becomes {@condition frightened|CRB} 2.
entries.Success: The target becomes {@condition frightened|CRB} 1.

action.name: Administer First Aid
action.requirements: You have {@item healer's tools|CRB}.
entries: You perform first aid on an adjacent creature that is {@condition dying|CRB} or bleeding. If a creature is both {@condition dying|CRB} and bleeding, choose which ailment you're trying to treat before you roll. You can Administer First Aid again to attempt to remedy the other effect.

items: {@b Stabilize} Attempt a {@skill Medicine} check on a creature that has 0 Hit Points and the {@condition dying|CRB} condition. The DC is equal to 5 + that creature's recovery roll DC (typically 15 + its dying value).

{@b Stop Bleeding} Attempt a {@skill Medicine} check on a creature that is taking {@condition persistent damage|CRB|persistent bleed damage} (page 452), giving them a chance to make another flat check to remove the {@condition persistent damage|CRB}. The DC is usually the DC of the effect that caused the bleed.

entries.Success: If you're trying to stabilize, the creature loses the {@condition dying|CRB} condition (but remains {@condition unconscious|CRB}). If you're trying to stop bleeding, the creature attempts a flat check to end the bleeding.
entries.Critical Failure: If you were trying to stabilize, the creature's {@condition dying|CRB} value increases by 1. If you were trying to stop bleeding, it immediately takes an amount of damage equal to its {@condition persistent damage|CRB|persistent bleed damage}.

action.name: Treat Disease
action.requirements: You have {@item healer's tools|CRB}.
entries: You spend at least 8 hours caring for a diseased creature. Attempt a {@skill Medicine} check against the disease's DC. After you attempt to Treat a Disease for a creature, you can't try again until after that creature's next save against the disease.

entries.Critical Success: You grant the creature a +4 circumstance bonus to its next saving throw against the disease.
entries.Success: You grant the creature a +2 circumstance bonus to its next saving throw against the disease.
entries.Critical Failure: Your efforts cause the creature to take a –2 circumstance penalty to its next save against the disease.

action.name: Treat Poison
action.requirements: You have {@item healer's tools|CRB}.
entries: You treat a patient to prevent the spread of poison. Attempt a {@skill Medicine} check against the poison's DC. After you attempt to Treat a Poison for a creature, you can't try again until after the next time that creature attempts a save against the poison.

entries.Critical Success: You grant the creature a +4 circumstance bonus to its next saving throw against the poison.
entries.Success: You grant the creature a +2 circumstance bonus to its next saving throw against the poison.
entries.Critical Failure: Your efforts cause the creature to take a –2 circumstance penalty to its next save against the poison.

action.name: Treat Wounds
action.requirements: You have {@item healer's tools|CRB}.
entries: You spend 10 minutes treating one injured living creature (targeting yourself, if you so choose). The target is then temporarily immune to Treat Wounds actions for 1 hour, but this interval overlaps with the time you spent treating (so a patient can be treated once per hour, not once per 70 minutes).

The {@skill Medicine} check DC is usually 15, though the GM might adjust it based on the circumstances, such as treating a patient outside in a storm, or treating magically cursed wounds. If you're an expert in Medicine, you can instead attempt a DC 20 check to increase the Hit Points regained by 10; if you're a master of Medicine, you can instead attempt a DC 30 check to increase the Hit Points regained by 30; and if you're legendary, you can instead attempt a DC 40 check to increase the Hit Points regained by 50. The damage dealt on a critical failure remains the same.
If you succeed at your check, you can continue treating the target to grant additional healing. If you treat them for a total of 1 hour, double the Hit Points they regain from Treat Wounds.
The result of your {@skill Medicine} check determines how many Hit Points the target regains.

entries.Critical Success: The target regains {@dice 4d8} Hit Points, and its wounded condition is removed.
entries.Success: The target regains {@dice 2d8} Hit Points, and its wounded condition is removed.
entries.Critical Failure: The target takes {@dice 1d8} damage

action.name: Command an Animal
entries: You issue an order to an animal. Attempt a {@skill Nature} check against the animal's Will DC. The GM might adjust the DC if the animal has a good attitude toward you, you suggest a course of action it was predisposed toward, or you offer it a treat.

You automatically fail if the animal is hostile or unfriendly to you. If the animal is helpful to you, increase your degree of success by one step. You might be able to Command an Animal more easily with a feat like Ride (page 266).

Most animals know the {@action Leap|CRB}, {@action Seek|CRB}, {@action Stand|CRB}, {@action Stride|CRB}, and {@action Strike|CRB} basic actions. If an animal knows an activity, such as a horse's Gallop, you can Command the Animal to perform the activity, but you must spend as many actions on Command an Animal as the activity's number of actions. You can also spend multiple actions to Command the Animal to perform that number of basic actions on its next turn; for instance, you could spend 3 actions to Command an Animal to Stride three times or to Stride twice and then Strike.

entries.Success: The animal does as you command on its next turn.
entries.Failure: The animal is hesitant or resistant, and it does nothing.
entries.Critical Failure: The animal misbehaves or misunderstands, and it takes some other action determined by the GM.

action.name: Perform
entries: When making a brief performance—one song, a quick dance, or a few jokes—you use the Perform action. This action is most useful when you want to prove your capability or impress someone quickly. Performing rarely has an impact on its own, but it might influence the DCs of subsequent {@skill Diplomacy} checks against the observers—or even change their attitudes—if the GM sees fit.

entries.Critical Success: Your performance impresses the observers, and they're likely to share stories of your ability.
entries.Success: You prove yourself, and observers appreciate the quality of your performance.
entries.Failure: Your performance falls flat.
entries.Critical Failure: You demonstrate only incompetence.

items.name: Expert
items.entry: audience of merchants or minor nobles

items.name: Master
items.entry: audience of high nobility or minor royalty

items.name: Legendary
items.entry: audience of major royalty or otherworldly beings

action.name: Create Forgery
entries: You create a forged document, usually over the course of a day or a week. You must have the proper writing material to create a forgery. When you Create a Forgery, the GM rolls a secret DC 20 {@skill Society} check. If you succeed, the forgery is of good enough quality that passive observers can't notice the fake. Only those who carefully examine the document and attempt a {@skill Perception} or {@skill Society} check against your {@skill Society} DC can do so.

If the document's handwriting doesn't need to be specific to a person, you need only to have seen a similar document before, and you gain up to a +4 circumstance bonus to your check, as well as to your DC (the GM determines the bonus). To forge a specific person's handwriting, you need a sample of that person's handwriting.

If your check result was below 20, the forgery has some obvious signs of being a fake, so the GM compares your result to each passive observer's {@skill Perception} DC or Society DC, whichever is higher, using the success or failure results below. Once the GM rolls your check for a document, that same result is used against all passive observers' DCs no matter how many creatures passively observe that document.

An observer who was fooled on a passive glance can still choose to closely scrutinize the documents on the lookout for a forgery, using different techniques and analysis methods beyond the surface elements you successfully forged with your original check. In that case, the observer can attempt a {@skill Perception} or {@skill Society} check against your {@skill Society} DC (if they succeed, they know your document is a forgery).

entries.Success: The observer does not detect the forgery.
entries.Failure: The observer knows your document is a forgery.

action.name: Conceal an Object
entries: You hide a small object on your person (such as a weapon of light Bulk). When you try to sneak a concealed object past someone who might notice it, the GM rolls your {@skill Stealth} check and compares it to this passive observer's {@skill Perception} DC. Once the GM rolls your check for a concealed object, that same result is used no matter how many passive observers you try to sneak it past. If a creature is specifically searching you for an item, it can attempt a {@skill Perception} check against your {@skill Stealth} DC (finding the object on success).

You can also conceal an object somewhere other than your person, such as among undergrowth or in a secret compartment within a piece of furniture. In this case, characters Seeking in an area compare their {@skill Perception} check results to your {@skill Stealth} DC to determine whether they find the object.

entries.Success: The object remains {@condition undetected|CRB}.
entries.Failure: The searcher finds the object.

action.name: Hide
entries: You huddle behind cover or greater cover or deeper into concealment to become hidden, rather than observed. The GM rolls your {@skill Stealth} check in secret and compares the result to the {@skill Perception} DC of each creature you're observed by but that you have cover or greater cover against or are concealed from. You gain the circumstance bonus from cover or greater cover to your check.

Success: If the creature could see you, you're now hidden from it instead of observed. If you were hidden from or undetected by the creature, you retain that condition.

If you successfully become hidden to a creature but then cease to have cover or greater cover against it or be concealed from it, you become observed again. You cease being hidden if you do anything except {@action Hide|CRB}, {@action Sneak|CRB}, or {@action Step|CRB}. If you attempt to {@action Strike|CRB} a creature, the creature remains {@condition flat-footed|CRB} against that attack, and you then become {@condition observed|CRB}. If you do anything else, you become {@condition observed|CRB} just before you act unless the GM determines otherwise. The GM might allow you to perform a particularly unobtrusive action without being noticed, possibly requiring another {@skill Stealth} check.
If a creature uses Seek to make you observed by it, you must successfully Hide to become hidden from it again.

action.name: Sneak
entries: You can attempt to move to another place while becoming or staying {@condition undetected|CRB}. {@action Stride|CRB} up to half your Speed. (You can use Sneak while {@action Burrow|CRB|Burrowing}, {@action Climb|CRB|Climbing}, {@action Fly|CRB|Flying}, or {@action Swim|CRB|Swimming} instead of Striding if you have the corresponding movement type; you must move at half that Speed.)

If you're {@condition undetected|CRB} by a creature and it's impossible for that creature to observe you (for a typical creature, this includes when you're {@condition invisible|CRB}, the observer is {@condition blinded|CRB}, or you're in darkness and the creature can't see in darkness), for any critical failure you roll on a check to Sneak, you get a failure instead. You also continue to be {@condition undetected|CRB} if you lose cover or greater cover against or are no longer concealed from such a creature. At the end of your movement, the GM rolls your {@skill Stealth} check in secret and compares the result to the {@skill Perception} DC of each creature you were {@condition hidden|CRB} from or {@condition undetected|CRB} by at the start of your movement. If you have cover or greater cover from the creature throughout your {@action Stride|CRB}, you gain the +2 circumstance bonus from cover (or +4 from greater cover) to your {@skill Stealth} check. Because you're moving, the bonus increase from {@action Take Cover|CRB|Taking Cover} doesn't apply. You don't get to roll against a creature if, at the end of your movement, you neither are concealed from it nor have cover or greater cover against it. You automatically become {@condition observed|CRB} by such a creature.

Success: You're {@condition undetected|CRB} by the creature during your movement and remain {@condition undetected|CRB} by the creature at the end of it.

If you successfully become {@condition hidden|CRB} to a creature but then cease to have cover or greater cover against it or be concealed from it, you become {@condition observed|CRB} again. You cease being {@condition hidden|CRB} if you do anything except {@action Hide|CRB}, Sneak, or {@action Step|CRB}. If you attempt to Strike a creature, the creature remains {@condition flat-footed|CRB} against that attack, and you then become observed. If you do anything else, you become {@condition observed|CRB} just before you act unless the GM determines otherwise. The GM might allow you to perform a particularly unobtrusive action without being noticed, possibly requiring another {@skill Stealth} check.
If a creature uses {@action Seek|CRB} to make you {@condition observed|CRB} by it, you must successfully {@action Hide|CRB} to become {@condition hidden|CRB} from it again.
entries.Failure: A telltale sound or other sign gives your position away, though you still remain unseen. You're {@condition hidden|CRB} from the creature throughout your movement and remain so.
entries.Critical Failure: You're spotted! You're observed by the creature throughout your movement and remain so. If you're {@condition invisible|CRB} and were {@condition hidden|CRB} from the creature, instead of being {@condition observed|CRB} you're {@condition hidden|CRB} throughout your movement and remain so.

action.name: Sense Direction
entries: Using the stars, the position of the sun, traits of the geography or flora, or the behavior of fauna, you can stay oriented in the wild. Typically, you attempt a {@skill Survival} check only once per day, but some environments or changes might necessitate rolling more often. The GM determines the DC and how long this activity takes (usually just a minute or so). More unusual locales or those you're unfamiliar with might require you to have a minimum proficiency rank to Sense Direction. Without a compass, you take a –2 item penalty to checks to Sense Direction.

entries.Critical Success: You get an excellent sense of where you are. If you are in an environment with cardinal directions, you know them exactly
entries.Success: You gain enough orientation to avoid becoming hopelessly lost. If you are in an environment with cardinal directions, you have a sense of those directions.

items.name: Untrained
items.entry: determine a cardinal direction using the sun

items.name: Trained
items.entry: find an overgrown path in a forest

items.name: Master
items.entry: navigate a byzantine labyrinth or relatively featureless desert

action.name: Cover Tracks
entries: You cover your tracks, moving up to half your travel Speed, using the rules on page 479). You don't need to attempt a {@skill Survival} check to cover your tracks, but anyone tracking you must succeed at a {@skill Survival} check against your Survival DC if it is higher than the normal DC to Track.
In some cases, you might Cover Tracks in an encounter. In this case, Cover Tracks is a single action and doesn't have the {@trait exploration} trait.

action.name: Track
entries: You follow tracks, moving at up to half your travel Speed, using the rules on page 479). After a successful check to Track, you can continue following the tracks at half your Speed without attempting additional checks for up to 1 hour. In some cases, you might Track in an encounter. In this case, Track is a single action and doesn't have the {@trait exploration} trait, but you might need to roll more often because you're in a tense situation. The GM determines how often you must attempt this check.

You attempt your {@skill Survival} check when you start Tracking, once every hour you continue tracking, and any time something significant changes in the trail. The GM determines the DCs for such checks, depending on the freshness of the trail, the weather, and the type of ground.

entries.Success: You find the trail or continue to follow the one you're already following.
entries.Failure: You lose the trail but can try again after a 1-hour delay.
entries.Critical Failure: You lose the trail and can't try again for 24 hours.

items.name: Untrained
items.entry: the path of a large army following a road

items.name: Trained
items.entry: relatively fresh tracks of a rampaging bear through the plains

items.name: Expert
items.entry: a nimble panther's tracks through a jungle, tracks after the rain

items.name: Master
items.entry: tracks after a winter snow, tracks of a mouse or smaller creature, tracks left on surfaces that can't hold prints like bare rock

items.name: Legendary
items.entry: old tracks through a windy desert's sands, tracks after a major blizzard or hurricane

action.name: Palm an Object
entries: Palming a small, unattended object without being noticed requires you to roll a single {@skill Thievery} check against the {@skill Perception} DCs of all creatures who are currently observing you. You take the object whether or not you successfully conceal that you did so. You can typically only Palm Objects of negligible Bulk, though the GM might determine otherwise depending on the situation.

entries.Success: The creature does not notice you Palming the Object.
entries.Failure: The creature notices you Palming the Object, and the GM determines the creature's response.

action.name: Steal
entries: You try to take a small object from another creature without being noticed. Typically, you can Steal only an object of negligible Bulk, and you automatically fail if the creature who has the object is in combat or on guard.

Attempt a {@skill Thievery} check to determine if you successfully Steal the object. The DC to Steal is usually the {@skill Perception} DC of the creature wearing the object. This assumes the object is worn but not closely guarded (like a loosely carried pouch filled with coins, or an object within such a pouch). If the object is in a pocket or similarly protected, you take a –5 penalty to your {@skill Thievery} check. The GM might increase the DC of your check if the nature of the object makes it harder to steal (such as a very small item in a large pack, or a sheet of parchment mixed in with other documents).

You might also need to compare your {@skill Thievery} check result against the {@skill Perception} DCs of observers other than the person wearing the object. The GM may increase the {@skill Perception} DCs of these observers if they're distracted.

entries.Success: You steal the item without the bearer noticing, or an observer doesn't see you take or attempt to take the item.
entries.Failure: The item's bearer notices your attempt before you can take the object, or an observer sees you take or attempt to take the item. The GM determines the response of any creature that notices your theft.

action.name: Disable a Device
action.requirements: Some devices require you to use {@item thieves' tools|CRB} (page 291) when disabling them.
entries: This action allows you to disarm a trap or another complex device. Often, a device requires numerous successes before becoming disabled, depending on its construction and complexity. Thieves' tools are helpful and sometimes even required to Disable a Device, as determined by the GM, and sometimes a device requires a higher proficiency rank in Thievery to disable it.
Your {@skill Thievery} check result determines how much progress you make.

entries.Critical Success: You disable the device, or you achieve two successes toward disabling a complex device. You leave no trace of your tampering, and you can rearm the device later, if that type of device can be rearmed.
entries.Success: You disable the device, or you achieve one success toward disabling a complex device.
entries.Critical Failure: You trigger the device.

action.name: Pick a Lock
action.requirements: You have {@item thieves' tools|CRB}.
entries: Opening a lock without a key is very similar to {@action Disable a Device|CRB|Disabling a Device}, but the DC of the check is determined by the complexity and construction of the lock you are attempting to pick (locks and their DCs are found on page 290). Locks of higher qualities might require multiple successes to unlock, since otherwise even an unskilled burglar could easily crack the lock by attempting the check until they rolled a natural 20. If you lack the proper tools, the GM might let you used improvised picks, which are treated as shoddy tools, depending on the specifics of the lock.

entries.Critical Success: You unlock the lock, or you achieve two successes toward opening a complex lock. You leave no trace of your tampering.
entries.Success: You open the lock, or you achieve one success toward opening a complex lock.
entries.Critical Failure: You break your tools. Fixing them requires using {@skill Crafting} to {@action Repair|CRB} them or else swapping in replacement picks (costing 3 sp, or 3 gp for {@item infiltrator thieves' tools|CRB}).

action.name: Avoid Notice
entries: You attempt a {@skill Stealth} check to avoid notice while traveling at half speed. If you have the {@feat Swift Sneak|CRB} feat, you can move at full Speed rather than half, but you still can't use another exploration activity while you do so. If you have the {@feat Legendary Sneak|CRB} feat, you can move at full Speed and use a second exploration activity. If you're Avoiding Notice at the start of an encounter, you usually roll a {@skill Stealth} check instead of a {@skill Perception} check both to determine your initiative and to see if the enemies notice you (based on their {@skill Perception} DCs, as normal for {@action Sneak|CRB}, regardless of their initiative check results).

action.name: Defend
entries: You move at half your travel speed with your shield raised. If combat breaks out, you gain the benefits of {@action Raise a Shield|CRB|Raising a Shield} before your first turn begins.

action.name: Follow the Expert
entries: Choose an ally attempting a recurring skill check while exploring, such as climbing, or performing a different exploration tactic that requires a skill check (like {@action Avoid Notice|CRB|Avoiding Notice}). The ally must be at least an expert in that skill and must be willing to provide assistance. While Following the Expert, you match their tactic or attempt similar skill checks. Thanks to your ally's assistance, you can add your level as a proficiency bonus to the associated skill check, even if you're untrained. Additionally, you gain a circumstance bonus to your skill check based on your ally's proficiency (+2 for expert, +3 for master, and +4 for legendary).

action.name: Affix a Talisman
action.requirements: You must use a {@item repair kit}.
entries: You spend 10 minutes affixing a talisman to an item, placing the item on a stable surface and using the {@item repair kit} with both hands. You can also use this activity to remove a talisman. If more than one talisman is affixed to an item, the talismans are suppressed; none of them can be activated.

action.name: Call on Ancient Blood
action.trigger: You attempt a saving throw against a {@trait magical} effect, but you haven't rolled yet.
entries: Your ancestors' innate resistance to magic surges, before slowly ebbing down. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus until the end of this turn. This bonus also applies to the triggering save.

action.name: Energy Emanation
entries: Energy bursts forth from your body. You deal {@dice 1d6} damage of your chosen type to all adjacent creatures (basic Reflex save using your class DC or spell DC, whichever is higher). At 3rd level, and every 2 levels thereafter, this damage increases by {@dice 1d6}.

action.name: Invoke Celestial Privilege
action.trigger: You attempt a saving throw against a {@trait divine} effect, but you haven't rolled yet.
entries: You rise above the triggering effect, refusing to be harmed by it. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to the triggering saving throw and to any other saving throws you attempt against {@trait divine} effects until the start of your next turn.

action.name: Invigorating Fear
action.trigger: A creature within 60 feet gains the {@condition frightened} condition.
entries: You are invigorated by the shock of a prank or the thrum of terror. You gain temporary Hit Points equal to the creature's level or 3, whichever is higher.

action.name: Tail Toxin
entries: You apply your tail's venom to a piercing or slashing weapon. If your next {@action Strike} with that weapon before the end of your next turn hits and deals damage, you deal {@condition persistent damage|CRB|persistent poison damage} equal to your level to the target.
action.requirements: You are wielding a piercing or slashing weapon.

action.name: Threatening Approach
entries: You {@action Stride} to be adjacent to a foe and {@action Demoralize} that foe. If you succeed, the foe is {@condition frightened} 2 instead of {@condition frightened} 1.

action.name: Quick Alchemy
action.requirements: You have the formula for the alchemical item you're creating, and you're either holding or wearing {@item alchemist's tools|CRB}.
entries: You swiftly mix up a short-lived alchemical item to use at a moment's notice. You create a single alchemical item of your advanced alchemy level or lower that's in your formula book without having to spend the normal monetary cost in alchemical reagents or needing to attempt a {@skill Crafting} check. This item has the {@trait infused} trait, but it remains potent only until the start of your next turn.

action.name: Mutagenic Flashback
entries: You experience a brief resurgence of a mutagen. Choose one mutagen you've consumed since your last daily preparations. You gain the effects of that mutagen for 1 minute.

action.name: Rage
action.requirements: You aren't {@condition fatigued} or raging.
entries: You tap into your inner fury and begin raging. You gain a number of temporary Hit Points equal to your level plus your Constitution modifier. This frenzy lasts for 1 minute, until there are no enemies you can perceive, or until you fall unconscious, whichever comes first. You can't voluntarily stop raging. While you are raging:

items: You deal 2 additional damage with melee weapons and unarmed attacks. This additional damage is halved if your weapon or unarmed attack is {@trait agile}.
You take a –1 penalty to AC.
You can't use actions with the {@trait concentrate} trait unless they also have the {@trait rage} trait. You can {@action Seek|CRB} while raging.

entries: After you stop raging, you lose any remaining temporary Hit Points from {@action Rage}, and you can't {@action Rage} again for 1 minute.

action.name: Mighty Rage
action.trigger: You use the {@action Rage} action on your turn.
entries: Use an action that has the {@trait rage} trait. Alternatively, you can increase the actions of the triggering {@action Rage} to 2 to instead use a 2-action activity with the rage trait.

Bloodshed begets bloodshed as you drag your enemy toward oblivion. You increase the amount of damage you take by 1d6, and you deal 1d6 damage to the triggering enemy, choosing evil or negative damage to deal to the enemy each time you use this reaction. In addition, until the end of your next turn, your Strikes against the triggering creature deal 2 extra damage of the type you chose.

The damage you take and deal when you use this reaction increases to 2d6 at 5th level, 3d6 at 9th level, 4d6 at 12th level, 5d6 at 16th level, and 6d6 at 19th level. The extra damage on your Strikes increases to 4 at 9th level and 6 at 16th level.
action.name: Destructive Vengeance
action.trigger: An enemy within 15 feet damages you.

entries: You protect your ally and strike your foe. The ally gains resistance to all damage against the triggering damage equal to 2 + your level. If the foe is within reach, make a melee Strike against it.
action.name: Retributive Strike
action.trigger: An enemy damages your ally, and both are within 15 feet of you.

entries: Your foe hesitates under the weight of sin as visions of redemption play in their mind's eye. The foe must choose one of the following options

items: The ally is unharmed by the triggering damage.
The ally gains resistance to all damage against the triggering damage equal to 2 + your level. After the damaging effect is applied, the enemy becomes enfeebled 2 until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Glimpse of Redemption
action.trigger: An enemy damages your ally, and both are within 15 feet of you.

entries: You free an ally from restraint. If the trigger was an ally taking damage, the ally gains resistance to all damage against the triggering damage equal to 2 + your level. The ally can attempt to break free of effects grabbing, restraining, immobilizing, or paralyzing them. They either attempt a new save against one such effect that allows a save, or attempt to {@action Escape} from one effect as a free action. If they can move, the ally can Step as a free action, even if they didn't need to escape.
action.name: Liberating Step
action.trigger: An enemy damages, Grabs, or {@action Grapple|CRB|Grapples} your ally, and both are within 15 feet of you.

entries: You put an impertinent foe who dared harm you in their proper place. You command your enemy to kneel before you in obedience. If they dare to refuse, they must pay the price in pain and anguish. The foe must choose one of the following options.

items: The enemy kneels, dropping prone as a free action.
The enemy refuses, and you deal 1d6 mental damage to it. This damage increases to 2d6 at 5th level, 3d6 at 9th level, 4d6 at 12th level, 5d6 at 16th level, and 6d6 at 19th level.

entries: In addition, your Strikes against the triggering creature deal 1 extra damage until the end of your next turn. You choose whether the damage type is evil or negative each time you use this reaction. This extra damage increases to 2 at 9th level and 3 at 16th level.
action.name: Iron Command
action.trigger: An enemy within 15 feet damages you.

entries: Your self-interest keeps you safe. You gain resistance against the triggering damage equal to 2 + half your level, regardless of damage type.

In addition, your Strikes against the triggering creature deal 1 extra damage until the end of your next turn. You choose whether this extra damage is evil or negative each time you use this reaction. This extra damage increases to 2 at 9th level and 3 at 16th level.
action.name: Selfish Shield
action.trigger: An enemy within 15 feet damages you.

action.name: Devise a Stratagem
action.trigger: Another creature attempts a check to investigate a lead you're pursuing.
entries: You assess a foe's weaknesses in combat and use them to formulate a plan of attack against your enemy. Choose a creature you can see and roll a {@dice d20}. If you {@action Strike} the chosen creature later this round, you must use the result of the roll you made to {@action Devise a Stratagem|APG} for your {@action Strike}'s attack roll instead of rolling. You make this substitution only for the first {@action Strike} you make against the creature this round, not any subsequent attacks.

When you make this substitution, you can also add your Intelligence modifier to your attack roll instead of your Strength or Dexterity modifier, provided your {@action Strike} uses an {@trait agile} or {@trait finesse} melee weapon, an {@trait agile} or {@trait finesse} unarmed attack, a ranged weapon (which must be {@trait agile} or {@trait finesse} if it's a melee weapon with the {@trait thrown} trait), or a {@item sap}.
If you're aware that the creature you choose is the subject of a lead you're pursuing, you can use this ability as a free action.

action.name: Pursue a Lead
entries: You spend 1 minute examining the details of one potential clue, designating the subject related to that clue as the target of your active investigation. This subject is typically a single creature, item, or small location (such as a room or corridor), but the GM might allow a different scope for your investigation. You don't need to know the identity, purpose, or nature of the subject, but you do need to be aware of its existence. For instance, finding a footprint is enough to investigate the creature that left it, and seeing a hasty sketch of an item or location can be enough to start your investigation of that subject.

Whenever you attempt a {@skill Perception} or skill check to investigate a designated subject, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to the check. The exact checks this applies to depend on the actions you use to investigate and are determined by the GM, but checks to investigate are typically {@skill Perception} checks or skill checks that use Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma.

You can maintain two active investigations at a time. If you Pursue another Lead after that, the subject must be different from any of your current investigations (or rather, they must be different as far as you know), and you give up on a current subject of your choice. Once you've given up pursuit of a subject, you can't Pursue that Lead again until after the next time you make your daily preparations.

action.name: Clue In
action.trigger: Another creature attempts a check to investigate a lead you're pursuing.
entries: You share information with the triggering creature. They gain a circumstance bonus to their check equal to your circumstance bonus to checks investigating your subject from {@action Pursue a Lead|APG}. The GM can add any relevant traits to this reaction depending on the situation, such as {@trait auditory} and {@trait linguistic} if you're conveying information verbally.

action.name: Quick Tincture
action.requirements: You know the formula for the alchemical item you're creating, you are holding or wearing {@item alchemist's tools|CRB}, and you have a free hand.
entries: You quickly brew up a short-lived tincture. You create a single alchemical elixir or tool of your level or lower without having to spend the normal monetary cost in alchemical reagents or needing to attempt a {@skill Crafting} check. This item has the {@trait infused} trait, but it remains potent only until the end of the current turn.

action.name: Expeditious Inspection
entries: You observe and assess your surroundings with great speed. You {@action Recall Knowledge}, {@action Seek}, or {@action Sense Motive}.

action.name: Pointed Question
entries: You ask a question that charms or needles someone in just the right way. Ask a question of a non-allied creature that you can see and have been conversing with. Attempt a {@skill Diplomacy} check against the creature's Will DC. The creature is then temporarily immune for 1 hour.

entries.Critical Success: The target must directly answer your question. It doesn't have to answer truthfully, but you gain a +4 circumstance bonus to your {@skill Perception} DC if the creature attempts to {@action Lie} to you.
entries.Success: As critical success, but the circumstance bonus is +2.
entries.Failure: The target can refuse to answer you as normal.
entries.Critical Failure: The target can refuse to answer you as normal, and its attitude toward you decreases by one step due to your aggravating attention.

action.name: Flurry of Blows
entries: Make two unarmed {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes}. If both hit the same creature, combine their damage for the purpose of resistances and weaknesses. Apply your multiple attack penalty to the Strikes normally. As it has the {@trait flourish} trait, you can use {@action Flurry of Blows} only once per turn.

action.name: Hunt Prey
entries: You designate a single creature as your prey and focus your attacks against that creature. You must be able to see or hear the prey, or you must be tracking the prey during exploration.

You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to {@skill Perception} checks when you {@action Seek} your prey and a +2 circumstance bonus to {@skill Survival} checks when you {@action Track} your prey. You also ignore the penalty for making ranged attacks within your second range increment against the prey you're hunting.

You can have only one creature designated as your prey at a time. If you use {@action Hunt Prey} against a creature when you already have a creature designated, the prior creature loses the designation and the new prey gains the designation. Your designation lasts until your next daily preparations.
You apply one of the following debilitations, which lasts until the end of your next turn.

items: {@b Debilitation} the target takes a –10-foot status penalty to its Speeds.
{@b Debilitation} The target becomes {@condition enfeebled} 1.

action.name: Debilitating Strike

entries: The target attempts a Fortitude save at your class DC. It then becomes temporarily immune to your Master Strike for 1 day.

entries.Critical Success: The target is unaffected.
entries.Success: The target is {@condition enfeebled} 2 until the end of your next turn.
entries.Failure: The target is {@condition paralyzed} for 4 rounds.
entries.Critical Failure: The target is {@condition paralyzed} for 4 rounds, knocked {@condition unconscious} for 2 hours, or killed (your choice).

action.name: Master Strike
Confident Finisher
entries: You make an incredibly graceful attack, piercing your foe's defenses. Make a {@action Strike} with a weapon or unarmed attack that would apply your precise strike damage, with the following failure effect.

entries.Failure: You deal half your precise strike damage to the target. This damage type is that of the weapon or unarmed attack you used for the {@action Strike}.

action.name: Drain Bonded Item
entries: You expend the power stored in your bonded item. During your turn, you gain the ability to cast one spell you prepared today and already cast, without spending a spell slot. You must still {@action Cast a Spell|CRB|Cast the Spell} and meet the spell's other requirements.

action.name: Conduct Energy
action.requirements: Your last action or spell this turn had the {@trait acid}, {@trait cold}, {@trait electricity}, {@trait fire}, or {@trait sonic} trait.
entries: You channel energy into your weapon. The weapon deals 1 additional damage per weapon damage die until the start of your next turn. This damage type matches the trait of the triggering action or spell. If your triggering action or spell had multiple eligible traits, you select one of those traits.
